entry.title: How to set Application Version for MDK Client?
entry.content:
How can I set  or find the Application Version of an MDK Client?

I am trying to restrict access to only certain compatible MDK Clients compatible with the metadata data deployed. There is a setting in Security to restrict client by Application Version. But I could not find how this can be set for an MDK Client.

Security / Application Version

 For an Android Build of MDK Client, I tried to set this in app.gradle as suggested in Application Versioning documentation for Android. This succeeded in onboarding the client, but failed later when synching with an error from Mobilink. So that is not the correct approach. 

I suppose there is a correct way to do this with MDK.

entry.title: Re: Groovy scrit error when canonicalize XML subtree
entry.content:
Hi @Chris1973 

Thanks for this suggestion, Actually I had used the cannicalize() too replace the canonicalizeSubtree().

After that it will fix the type mismatch error, but it will brings a new problem:

In the original xml document before canonicalize, the namespace declaration are centrally put in the root </invoice> element just as below:

<Invoice xmlns="urn:oasis:names:specification:ubl:schema:xsd:Invoice-2" xmlns:cac="urn:oasis:names:specification:ubl:schema:xsd:CommonAggregateComponents-2" xmlns:cbc="urn:oasis:names:specification:ubl:schema:xsd:CommonBasicComponents-2">
<cbc:ID>Test</cbc:ID>
<cbc:IssueDate>2025-07-31</cbc:IssueDate>
<cbc:IssueTime>13:00:19Z</cbc:IssueTime>
<cbc:InvoiceTypeCode listVersionID="1.1">01</cbc:InvoiceTypeCode>
<cbc:DocumentCurrencyCode>EUR</cbc:DocumentCurrencyCode>
<cbc:TaxCurrencyCode>EUR</cbc:TaxCurrencyCode>

However after canonicalize() run, the namespace declaration will be separated into each child element just as below sample:

<Invoice xmlns="urn:oasis:names:specification:ubl:schema:xsd:Invoice-2">
  <cbc:ID xmlns:cbc="urn:oasis:names:specification:ubl:schema:xsd:CommonBasicComponents-2">Test</cbc:ID>
  <cbc:IssueDate xmlns:cbc="urn:oasis:names:specification:ubl:schema:xsd:CommonBasicComponents-2">2025-07-31</cbc:IssueDate>
  <cbc:IssueTime xmlns:cbc="urn:oasis:names:specification:ubl:schema:xsd:CommonBasicComponents-2">13:00:19Z</cbc:IssueTime>
  <cbc:InvoiceTypeCode xmlns:cbc="urn:oasis:names:specification:ubl:schema:xsd:CommonBasicComponents-2" listVersionID="1.1">01</cbc:InvoiceTypeCode>
  <cbc:DocumentCurrencyCode xmlns:cbc="urn:oasis:names:specification:ubl:schema:xsd:CommonBasicComponents-2">EUR</cbc:DocumentCurrencyCode>
  <cbc:TaxCurrencyCode xmlns:cbc="urn:oasis:names:specification:ubl:schema:xsd:CommonBasicComponents-2">EUR</cbc:TaxCurrencyCode>

The program will next steps use the canonicalized XMl to do the SHA-256 hash and Base 64 encode, then signing based on that digest .As a result the information in invoice  cannot match with the original invoice before canonicalize.

The basic logic is that the invoice verification system will also digest the original invoice, and compare the digest value with the result in signature. In this case the digest value will be different, because the invoice payload was changed after canonicalize.

Sincerely grateful for any suggestion which can avoid the namespace and format changed during the canonicalize() method run.

Thanks again!!

BR,

Ivan

entry.title: Re: Unable to see list data when I run the app
entry.content:
Hello @Ankita_Mundhra 

If you're using SAP Build Apps (or AppGyver):

Your integration query already fetches data successfully.

The issue lies in how that data is being linked to your UI, not the query itself.

As long as your data variable is correctly set to autoload and the UI is properly bound to that variable, the data should display.

Please double-check below

Is the data variable set to autoload?
If not, set it to autoload or use page logic to trigger it.

Is the UI element (e.g., table or list) bound to the data variable ‚Äî not the query?
Must be bound to the data variable, not the integration directly.

Is the data structure correct and accessible?
Use a temporary text element:{{ JSON.stringify(yourDataVariable) }}

This shows what‚Äôs actually in the variable during runtime.

Let me know if it works

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: freight-cost-condition divided per position in outbound delivery the same as at sales documents.
entry.content:
For example situation now : 

ZFRE= our freight-condition. | ZFRE= 10 euro. 

So order situation:

Product X | 2 pieces | 10 euro p/piece | therefore : ZFRE = 10/25*20 = 8 euro. 

  • 10 = ZFRE-freight. 
  • 25 comes from 10+10+5 total document costs.
  • 20=10+10 this position.

Product Y | 1 piece | 5 euro p/piece | therefore : ZFRE = 10/25*5 = 2 euro. 

  • 10 = ZFRE-freight. 
  • 25 comes from 10+10+5 total document costs.
  • 5= this position.

first outbound delivery / billing document:

Product X with 1 less piece:

Product X | 1 pieces | 10 euro | therefore : ZFRE = 10/25*10 = 4 euro. 

Product Y | 1 piece | 5 euro | therefore : ZFRE = 10/25*5 = 2 euro. 

SAP waits for next outbound deliveries for further ZFRE of 10-4-2=4 euro on position 1. 

--------------------------------------------------

Question: how to:

order situation same:

Product X | 2 pieces | 10 euro p/piece | therefore : ZFRE = 10/25*20 = 8 euro. 

Product Y | 1 piece | 5 euro p/piece | therefore : ZFRE = 10/25*5 = 2 euro. 

first delivery/billing document:

Product X with 1 piece on position 1 : 

Product X | 1 pieces |10 euro | ZFRE = 10/15*10 = 6.67 euro. 

Product Y | 1 piece |5 euro | ZFRE=10/15*5 = 3.33 euro. 

 

So we want:

At first delivery we want the 10 euro freight divided but calculated based on positions at outbound delivery. Next upcoming deliveries are then without freight costs because it is already payed. How could we do this ?

entry.title: How to Count Table Entries with a Custom KPI
entry.content:
With custom KPIs in Business Process Monitoring, you can enrich the application with further KPIs tailored to your needs. 

SAP Cloud ALM: Business Process Monitoring

This blog will explain how custom KPIs in Business Process Monitoring in SAP Cloud ALM can be used to count entries in a table.
It is a simple example, aiming to inspire what's in and what you could do.

 

General Information

The general process for a custom KPI is as follows:

Process Flow: Custom KPIs

The process for custom KPIs starts with their definition, followed by general and KPI-specific steps, and ends with using custom KPIs.

And in addition, the detailed flow for custom KPI for an ABAP-based component, which we will now follow:

Process Flow: Custom KPI for ABAP-based components

If you would like to learn more about custom KPIs, our Expert Portal (Custom KPIs) and the SAP Help Portal (Custom KPIs) are amazing places to go to. 

 

Before you Begin

Here are three things that are relevant before you can start:

  • In order to use a custom KPI for an ABAP-based component, the respective setup for Business Process Monitoring needs to be completed, and active, successful data collection is needed. You can find all relevant details on the Expert Portal: Custom KPIs - Prerequisites and Setup 
  • To define a custom KPI, you need to have the role of Process Monitoring Administrator
  • For the instrumentation of the KPI, bring some ABAP development knowledge

Let's get started with some context.

 

Context

We will create a custom KPI for ABAP-based components. As data model - tables for which we will count entries the famous sflight model.

As a result, the following queries shall be covered by the KPI:

  1. Total number of flights
  2. Number of flights operated with a 737-800
  3. Number of single flight bookings
  4. Number of flights that are scheduled
  5. Number of flights operated with a 777-300

Let's follow the steps mentioned above.

 

Steps for a Custom KPI

The following section will guide you through the process that results in a custom KPI. In the section "Use Custom KPI", you can also find examples of events based on the counters above. 

 

A) General Business Process Monitoring Steps

In order to use a custom KPI for an ABAP-based component, the respective setup for Business Process Monitoring needs to be completed, and active, successful data collection is needed.

You can find all relevant details on the Expert Portal: Custom KPIs - Prerequisites and Setup 

 

B) Custom KPI Definition

As this example will offer all checks collectively in a single KPI, this is how the KPI is defined:

Technical IDLabel
IDID
Field1Check No
Field2Table
Field3Number of Entries
Field4 Additional Criteria 1
Field5  Additional Criteria 2
Field6Label
TIMESTAMP_UTCTimestamp

In the Business Process Monitoring application

  • Open the configuration panel
  • Expand the sections Managed Components > KPI Management
  • Choose Configure KPIs
  • In the KPI Management, choose + to Create a Custom KPI

For information and characteristics, specify the relevant details ‚Äì in our example

InformationCharacteristics
Name: Flight Counters
Description: Flight Counters
KPI ID: ZKPITA0999
Category: Backlog
Data Collection Frequency: 15 Minutes		FIELD_1 Check No
FIELD_2 Table
FIELD_3 Number of Entries
FIELD_4 Additional Criteria 1
FIELD_5 Additional Criteria 2
FIELD_6 Label 

Result:

Business Process Monitoring: KPI Definition

 

C) Instrument KPI

The following steps show the instrumentation in the managed component and require ABAP development knowledge:

  • Create a subclass of /SDF/CL_CRBPA_CKPI:
    Instrumentation: Class Properties
  • Redefine method GET_KPI_ID and GET_DATA:
    Instrumentation: Redefined Methods
    Instrumentation: Method GET_KPI_IDInstrumentation: Method GET_DATA

 

D) Auto-Discovery and Data Collection

These steps are taken care of automatically for you based on our framework.

No manual activities required - only giving it some time üòâ

 

E) Use Custom KPI

The result in the application looks as follows:

Business Process Monitoring: KPI Details

Let's proceed with the definition of an Event: to receive an email notification.

 

Define Event

What would be a KPI without an event or being alerted? Let's have a look at two examples, one for counter 2 and the second for counter 5.

Here is the definition for getting an alert if there are results for counter 2:
Business Process Monitoring: Event Definition Counter 2

And as you can see in the KPI details above, relevant entries are found - the resulting notification: 

Event: Notification

Similarly, you can also define an event for counter 5 - this looks as follows
Business Process Monitoring: Event Definition Counter 5

In this case, the expected result is no email. Currently, there is no flight in the data that is operated with 777-300. Once there is a respective data set, it will be identified as part of the next data collection, with this visible in the KPI details. Based on the event definition, an alert and email notification will be triggered. 

 

Summarizing

So let's summarize: this blog explains, based on an example, how to use a custom KPI to count table entries.

We chose the way, one single KPI that covers all counters. Many other options are possible. So it is now your turn to get started!

Happy to hear from you how you used it, so feel free to leave a comment below.

entry.title: Where can I start learning how to manage SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition implementations?
entry.content:
I recommend to access our Managing SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition Projects   learning journey.

Overview
This Learning Journey is designed for experienced SAP professionals, including project managers, consultants, and technical leads, who seek to enhance their skills in managing SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition implementations. It is particularly suited for individuals aspiring to advance their careers by taking on strategic, high-level roles in cloud-based project delivery and enterprise integration.

Learning objectives
Within this Learning Journey, SAP project managers can deepen their expertise of managing SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition implementations, specifically focusing on SAP tools, methodologies, and SAP Business Suite portfolio.

This Learning Journey will lead to the certification "Managing SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition Projects", which includes courses on the following subjects:

  1. Exploring SAP Activate - Implementation Tools and Methodology
  2. Implementing SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
  3. Discovering Organizational Change Management for SAP Cloud Projects
  4. Introducing the RISE with SAP Methodology for SAP Partners and Customers

Prerequisites

  • Project Management Experience: Minimum of 5‚Äì7 years managing ERP implementation projects, preferably SAP Cloud-related
  • SAP Expertise: Hands-on experience with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition, including system deployment, configuration, and lifecycle management
  • Cloud Implementation Experience: Proven track record in managing cloud-based SAP projects, including understanding of SaaS models

Please post you question related to the digital learning Journey in the Q&A area. 
Our SAP Learning Experts will get back to you as soon as possible! 
We are here to support you.


I appreciate your feedback and we will make sure to continue sharing interesting topics.

entry.title: Have You Heard About Service Management Solutions from SAP?
entry.content:
How One Service Call Turned Into a Business Breakthrough

It started with a broken compressor on a hot summer day.

Anna, a service manager at an industrial equipment company, got the call: a key customer‚Äôs machine had failed‚Äîand production was at risk. The clock was ticking, and the pressure was on. In the past, resolving a case like this would have meant a flurry of phone calls, digging through disconnected systems for warranty info, manually checking technician availability, and hoping the right spare part was in stock.

But not this time.

Thanks to SAP‚Äôs end-to-end Service Management solution, Anna‚Äôs team had everything they needed in one place‚Äîfrom customer contract details and installed base info to intelligent technician scheduling, mobile field execution, and real-time updates. Within hours, the right technician was on-site with the correct spare part. The issue was fixed before it became a crisis.

And the customer? Still a customer. More loyal than ever.

Service: The New Competitive Edge

In today‚Äôs service economy, it‚Äôs no longer enough to sell great products. Customers expect fast, reliable, and proactive service. That‚Äôs where Service Management solutions from SAP come in‚Äîhelping companies like Anna‚Äôs turn every service interaction into a competitive advantage.

SAP connects the dots across your entire service lifecycle, from the initial request to billing and performance analysis. It‚Äôs not just about solving issues‚Äîit‚Äôs about transforming service into a strategic driver of growth, loyalty, and efficiency.

What‚Äôs Included in SAP‚Äôs Service Management Offering?

 

üõíSell, Contract, and Engage

  • Manage subscriptions and complex service contracts with Services in SAP Cloud ERP.

  • Provide fast, omnichannel support via SAP Service Cloud.

üì¶Plan, Optimize, and Orchestrate

  • Predict equipment failures with SAP Asset Performance Management.

  • Ensure parts and labor are ready when needed with integrated planning tools.

üß≠ Schedule and Execute

  • Use AI-powered scheduling in SAP Field Service Management to dispatch the right technician at the right time.

  • Empower your field force with intuitive mobile apps‚Äîeven when offline.

üí∞Invoice and Close

  • Automate warranty handling, returns, and billing with Finance in SAP Cloud ERP.

  • Gain full visibility into service profitability and cost-to-serve.

Why Do Customers Choose SAP?

Because SAP doesn‚Äôt just offer tools‚Äîit offers transformation.

 

‚úÖIntegrated by Design

Service Management solutions from SAP are part of the broader SAP Business Suite. That means seamless handovers, no duplicate data entry, and no fragile third-party integrations.

‚úÖBuilt for Intelligence

With SAP Business AI and automation embedded, SAP helps your team make smarter decisions‚Äîfaster.

‚úÖFlexible and Future-Proof

Whether you‚Äôre scaling field operations, managing complex SLAs, or building a partner network, SAP adapts to your service strategy.

From One Service Call to a Strategic Shift

Back to Anna: what started as one resolved breakdown evolved into a deeper realization. With SAP, her company didn‚Äôt just fix machines faster‚Äîthey started rethinking service delivery entirely. Today, they offer predictive maintenance packages, use data to improve uptime, and collaborate more closely with partners.

Service became more than a cost center. It became a value engine.

Curious How It Could Work for You?

Let‚Äôs talk. We‚Äôll show you how SAP Service Management can help you:

  • Streamline your service processes

  • Improve customer satisfaction

  • Boost service revenue

  • Make sustainability a differentiator

üëâContact us to schedule a demo or learn more.

entry.title: Re: validity update in mass changes to purchasing info re...
entry.content:
You need to:

  • Maintain 'X' in column Is New so a new record is created
  • In the condition group ID field, maintain new dummy nrs (just 1,2,3,4,5 etc) and update the validaty period from date with the new period for the new condition, a new condition record will be created
  • No need to put end date in the existing condition item line like the other commenter has said. you can just overwrite that data with new data and it will delimit that condition record automatically when you create the new one.

entry.title: Re: BAS Connection to On-Premises System Failing with 'Re...
entry.content:
Hi @s_sudhirkumar 

Based on the behaviour you mentioned, the problem is likely tied to certain configuration mismatches between BAS and the backend system despite the destination working in Build Apps and BTP cockpit.

To evaluate the source, I suggest you do the following:

  • Ensure your Cloud Connector mappings are correctly set up and the system is marked as ‚ÄúAvailable‚Äù.
  • Make sure to confirm that the OData service is active in SICF and properly whitelisted.
  • Double-check that your destination settings in BTP match what is expected by BAS
  • If needed, you can enable backend trace like ST01 or SMICM to catch dropped connections or blocked services.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: BW: True impact of build statistics in cubes.
entry.content:
Hi @luisaguilar 

Thanks for your question.

SAP generally recommends that you update statistics as follows:

  • After each full load or major delta load to the InfoCube, especially if data volume has changed significantly.
  • Not necessarily after every delta, unless the volume or pattern significantly impacts data distribution.

Regarding the data requirement:

  • For Oracle, SAP suggests you build statistics on a representative sample, though this can be tuned based on data skew.
  • For HANA, it's less critical because HANA auto-manages statistics, but for classic BW on non-HANA DBs scheduling statistics explicitly is beneficial.

Here is what I recommend:

Include "Build Statistics" in process chains after heavy loads but avoid overuse for minor delta updates.

Optionally, you can set thresholds or conditional branches to execute statistics only if the load exceeds a certain volume.

To summarize, updating statistics after large or full loads helps significantly improve query performance by enabling better data access planning. For smaller delta loads, it's not always necessary unless there's a major shift in data volume or distribution.

For non-HANA databases, including the "Build Statistics" step in process chains post-load is recommended. Ideally use a sample percentage of approximately 10% to balance performance and accuracy. HANA manages this more automatically, so the need is less critical there.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: comparison scripting
entry.content:
Let's hope scripting capabilities arrive someday in the tool, because simple version-to-version comparisons are often difficult to grasp by story builders.
- Restricted/calculated measures/accounts are often a place I want to keep reserved for other business logic then simply a version variance.
- It becomes harder because of 2 different approaches & visualization styles in tables & charts variances.

There have been quite some influence requests related to these topics with a LOT of votes, so I would suggest you vote for at least these 2 requests:
https://influence.sap.com/sap/ino/#/idea/275936 
https://influence.sap.com/sap/ino/#/idea/308765

entry.title: Re: Unable to completely terminate a TRM Transaction
entry.content:
When you ‚ÄúGive Notice/Terminate‚Äù an FTR deal in FTR_EDIT and settle all cash-flows, you still need to trigger its final business event so that the activity status flips to ‚ÄúCompleted/Contract Settled.‚Äù If you skip that, the system sees the deal as still active‚Äîand reprotects it against further termination attempts, leading to BS013.

Here‚Äôs how to close the loop:

In FTR_EDIT, open your deal and choose Goto ‚Üí Cash Flows. Confirm no lines are left ‚ÄúFlagged for Fixing‚Äù or ‚ÄúTo Be Processed.‚Äù If any remain: Select them ‚Üí ‚ÄúFix Pay & Post.‚Äù Save and refresh until the list is empty. When zero flows remain, you‚Äôre ready for the final event.

In FTR_EDIT, open the same deal. Click Additional Functions ‚Üí Post Business Events. In the popup, select the termination event (usually event type ‚Äú900 ‚Äì Contract Termination‚Äù or your custom variant). Execute. This step writes the termination into the deal‚Äôs event log and officially closes the contract in SAP‚Äôs event processor.

Once the termination event is posted, go back in FTR_EDIT, refresh the header. The Activity Status should now read ‚ÄúCompleted‚Äù or ‚ÄúContract Settled.‚Äù Save your deal again. If status doesn‚Äôt update, it often means the event wasn‚Äôt processed or there‚Äôs a custom event determination gap.

entry.title: Re: SAP PaPM Cloud Standard Model: Modeling Update (Join)
entry.content:
@Paulo_Moncada

We would like to express our concern regarding the recent changes to the join function, specifically the inability to select fields from individual join rules in the final join configuration. This functionality was previously available and played a crucial role in streamlining our solutions.

Unfortunately, the current limitation has significantly increased our effort and complexity, making the process more cumbersome. It has now been over three months without a resolution, and we are increasingly dissatisfied with the way recent releases have been rolled out‚Äîoften without sufficient support or consideration for customer impact.

We strongly believe that the ability to copy fields from each individual join rule, rather than solely from the function signature, is a more flexible and user-friendly approach. This was a key feature in the previous version and should be considered essential moving forward.

We kindly request that this issue be prioritized and addressed at the earliest possible opportunity. If a fix is already planned or in progress, we would appreciate insights into the expected timeline for delivery.

Thank you for your attention to this matter. We look forward to your response and a resolution that restores the usability we previously relied on.

Best regards,

Gopi Akkapeddi

entry.title: Setting Up Individual Goals in PMGM with Varying Targets | Metric-LookUp Table
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

At our company, we use individual goals in the Performance and Goal Management module, each with different target levels (=Targets).

Since the SAP release H01/2025, we‚Äôve encountered an issue in the Performance & Goals module: we can no longer set individual target levels for our goals. Instead, the same target levels are shown for all individual goals. Even when we adjust and save the target levels for a specific individual goal in SuccessFactors, the changes are not applied. SuccessFactors continues to display the default target levels used for all individual goals (please see the screenshots below).

For example, when we try to adjust the target levels for the individual goal "EBIT Asia" (Screenshot 1) and then click save, the system still shows the targets 0, 100, and 200 (Screenshot 2).

Screenshot 1: Trying to change the target levels of the individual goal "EBIT ASIA" by clicking "save"

Screenshot 2: SAP SuccessFactors does not consider the saved changes and continues to show the target levels 0, 100, 200

 

 

We assume that the values 0, 100, and 200 are defined in the Metric Lookup Table in the XML file, which is why they are always shown as default for individual goals.

Now that we have the issue of needing different targets for different individual goals, but the system only displays the same targets for all, my question is:
Is there a way to configure the system so that each individual goal can have its own target level again?
Or has anyone else experienced this issue and found a solution?

Many thanks in advance for your help.

entry.title: Re: Error in calling Outbound Delivery public API in iflo...
entry.content:
Hi @Priyanka488 

Thank you for your question.

Based on the details you provided, the error you're facing in your iFlow when calling the API_OUTBOUND_DELIVERY_SRV via the OData V2 Receiver Adapter stems from an improperly formatted query string specifically. It refers to how the ‚Äú&‚Äù characters are used in the select, expand, and filter parts of the URL.

SAP confirms this as a known issue (see SAP Note 2510796), where the adapter throws an internal parsing error if & characters are misplaced.

To fix it, make sure your query string is well-structured.

Once the URL syntax is corrected, your GET request should work as expected.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Issue with Translating Simulation into English
entry.content:
Hello @Helenka ,

Yes, you can use the "Export Translation File" functionality for simulations, including Demo, Practice, and Test modes in SAP Enable Now (cloud or on-premise). However, there are a few important things to note:

  1. All Modes Must Be Generated
    Ensure that Demo, Practice, and Test modes are already generated for each simulation. Otherwise, they won‚Äôt be included in the export file.
  2. Structure Consistency
    If some simulations are not exporting correctly, check:
  • If their structure deviates from standard templates
  • If any screens or steps are incomplete or corrupted
  • If language placeholders are missing

3.Use Translation Hub or External Tools
Once you export the XLIFF translation file, you can use tools like:

  • SAP Translation Hub
  • Third-party CAT tools (e.g., SDL Trados, MemoQ)

After translating, you can re-import the file to update the original simulation content in bulk.

4. Check Project Type
Only multilingual projects allow full translation export. Confirm your project settings are set to support multiple languages.

Troubleshooting Tip

  • If some simulations are still excluded:
  • Open one of the problematic simulations
  • Regenerate all three modes (Demo, Practice, Test)
  • Save and try exporting again

SAP Help Confirmation: SAP Enable Now Help Portal ‚Äì Translations

Let me know if it works

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Need Help Converting Functional Specification to CDS...
entry.content:
Hi,

Here are the steps on how to build CDS views in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. The Functional Specification Document from you needs deeper review from a dedicated consultant, though. 

Prerequisites

  • Ensure you have the "Extensibility" business catalog assigned to your business role [1]
  • Access to the Custom CDS Views application through the Fiori Launchpad

Step-by-Step Process

1. Access the Custom CDS Views Application

  • Navigate to the "Custom CDS Views" tile in your Fiori Launchpad [2]
  • Click "Create" to start building a new custom CDS view [3]

2. Define Basic Properties

  • Label: Provide a descriptive name for your CDS view
  • Name: Enter a technical name following SAP naming conventions
  • Scenario: Select the appropriate scenario:
    • Analytical: For reporting and analytics use cases
    • Transactional: For operational scenarios
    • Value Help: For dropdown lists and search helps [4]

3. Configure Data Sources

  • Primary Data Source: Select your main CDS view from the available released views [1]
  • Associated Data Sources: Add related views as needed
  • Define join conditions between data sources with appropriate cardinality settings [3]

4. Select Elements and Fields

  • Navigate to the "Elements" tab
  • Choose fields from your primary and associated data sources
  • Configure field properties such as:
    • Labels and descriptions
    • Data types
    • Aggregation behaviors for analytical scenarios [3]

5. Add Calculations and Logic

  • Implement calculations directly within the custom CDS view
  • Use built-in functions and expressions for data transformation
  • For analytical scenarios, add restricted measures and calculated measures [5]

6. Define Parameters and Filters

  • Set up input parameters for dynamic filtering
  • Configure default values and validation rules
  • Add selection criteria to optimize data retrieval [1]

7. Testing and Validation

  • Use the "Data Preview" function to verify your CDS view structure
  • Check for any errors or warnings in the system logs
  • Validate that all joins and calculations work correctly [3]

8. Publish and Activate

  • Click "Check" to validate the CDS view definition
  • Resolve any issues identified during the check
  • Click "Publish" to activate your custom CDS view [3]

Best Practices

  • Follow SAP's content guidelines as outlined in SAP Note 2540696 [6]
  • Implement proper authorization checks for data security
  • Use meaningful names and descriptions for better maintainability
  • Test thoroughly with representative data volumes
  • Consider performance implications when joining multiple data sources

Integration Options

  • Analytics: Use with Custom Analytical Queries for reporting [5]
  • External APIs: Expose as OData services for external consumption [2]
  • Custom Fields: Extend with custom fields created through Key User Extensibility [7]

[1]: How to Create Custom CDS Views for SAP Marketing Cloud

[2]: Custom CDS Views ‚Äì Frequently Asked Questions

[3]: How to create CDS View Report In RISE With SAP Public Cloud 2208

[4]: Overview of S/4HANA Cloud reporting capabilities utilizing custom CDS views and eSAC - Part 1

[5]: Custom Logic for the fields in Custom CDS (S4 Public Cloud)
[6]: Custom CDS Views
[7]: How to Extend Custom Fields for a Custom CDS View in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
 
Best regards, Dequan Xu

entry.title: Introducing the Get Certified Series for SAP Customer Data Cloud
entry.content:
We are thrilled to announce the launch of our new live session series: Get Certified for SAP Customer Data Cloud. This series is designed to help you prepare for and succeed in the C_C4H62 certification: SAP Certified Associate - Implementation Consultant - SAP Customer Data Cloud. Our certified expert trainers will guide you through all the relevant topic areas, ensuring you have the best chance of passing the certification exam.

Series Overview

The Get Certified live session series aims to provide you with expert-guided support to complement your self-study activities. By participating in these sessions, you will gain a deeper understanding of the exam format, scope, and key topics, enhancing your readiness to attempt the certification.

Prerequisites

To make the most of this series, we recommend that you:

  • Attend our Instructional-Led-Training.
  • Work through the learning journeys linked to this blog post.
  • Perform the hands-on practice exercises.
  • Join all the live sessions to benefit from the trainer's expertise and insights.

Session Breakdown

Each session will focus on specific topics relevant to the C_C4H62 certification exam. Here‚Äôs a breakdown of the content covered in each session:

Session 1: Kick Off (1 hour)

  • Outlining the live session series
  • Introducing the certification
  • Explaining the types of questions
  • Providing tips for preparation
  • Working through sample questions in the exam interface

Session 2: SAP Customer Identity and Access (2 hours)

  • Deep dive into SAP Customer Identity and Access
  • Key concepts and practical applications
  • Exam-focused insights and tips

Session 3: SAP Customer Data Cloud Authentication Methods (1 hour)

  • Understanding various authentication methods
  • Best practices and implementation strategies
  • Exam preparation for authentication topics

Session 4: SAP Enterprise Consent and Preference Management (1 hour)

  • Exploring consent and preference management in SAP Customer Data Cloud
  • How to configure and manage consent
  • Practical tips for the exam

Session 5: Developing and Integration with SAP Customer Data Cloud (2 hours)

  • Development and integration techniques
  • Hands-on exercises and best practices
  • Exam-specific guidance

Learning Objectives

By the end of this Get Certified live session series, you will be well-prepared to:

  • Understand the format and scope of the C_C4H62 certification exam.
  • Master key topics related to SAP Customer Data Cloud, including identity and access, authentication methods, consent and preference management, and integration techniques.
  • Feel confident in attempting the C_C4H62 certification exam.

Relevant Learning Journeys

To maximize your preparation(best before attending the get certified series), review the following Trainings and Learning Journeys:

  • Managing Clean Core for SAP S/4HANA Cloud
  • SAP Customer Data Cloud Implementation Training  
  • Exploring SAP Customer Data Cloud Essentials
  • From Onboarding to Governance: Mastering SAP Customer Data Cloud for B2B

How to Participate

 

For registration, simply log in with your valid Learning Hub subscription (for SAP internal teams, it‚Äôs FREE) and register to reserve your spot.

Get ready to enhance your SAP skills and take your career to the next level with the Get Certified Series for SAP Customer Data Cloud!

Don‚Äôt miss this opportunity to become a certified SAP Customer Data Cloud Implementation Consultant. See you in the sessions!

entry.title: Re: SAP Signavio Process insights
entry.content:
Hi @Nagendra24 

Just to clarify your question, it is not directly possible to identify unanalysed processes using admin access in the BTP Cockpit. The cockpit is focused on system-level configuration, not process analytics.

To check which processes are yet to be analysed I suggest you:

  • Use the ‚ÄúData Coverage‚Äù view in Signavio Process Insights. It shows which process metrics are missing or incomplete.
  • Optionally, review extractor job status in the source ERP system using transaction /N/SIGI/EX_MONITOR.
  • Ensure all required systems and APIs are correctly connected in the BTP cockpit, though this will not show you process-level details.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: What Procurement Gets Wrong About Supplier Onboarding
entry.content:
Hello Alia 

A big thanks for this quick blog as it highlights really some key aspects on the "business/organizational/processes" challenges of supplier onboarding (and I imagine in relation with ARIBA SLP).

Still I would highlight as well that the "technical process" of onboarding between the 2 IT platforms SLP and SBN still needs a lot of improvements to bring a "top of the notch" experience and that most of the time supplier people are very confused by the process putting a lot of workload on the buyer side to build some "out of system" process to decrease the confusion... A few example of pains points or improvements going from very basic things to complex ones :

1- First entry/login web page for a supplier that want to onboard: 

  • Supplier user is confused as the term "account" is used in this web page for both user account and company account(ANID). This could be confusing for him
  • Left panel tile is showing first some marketing stuff about ARIBA instead of showing the info about the buyer company sending the request (and honestly the supplier user will not know that he needs to flip the tile to see this info...)
  • Not possible for the buyer to include in this page a message in an information tile (text box) that could contain some extra information  from the buyer to help the supplier to register/onboard

2- SLP supplier whole process to onboard and fulfill questionnaires

  • The UX is very old-fashioned and not very flexible  and can confused Suppliers users a lot of time as there is not really any dynamic explanation. Now SAP owns a fantastic adoption platform in SAP "Walk Me" and it would be very nice that the buyer can push some guidance with Walkme to the supplier side (and I know WalkMe is available on Buyer side with August release but here the big added value would be to push guidance on; supplier side)

3- Supplier confusion about technical term and concept like ANID, account Admin...

  • As soon as the supplier (as a company) is already active in the network (for ARIBA Buying for example) but the supplier user being contacted is not aware about it, his path to reach the questionnaire is a big challenge : he is not aware about what is an ANID , what is the value ? He can contact the company admin in SBN but without any message (it is hard coded) and worse, not sure the admin is still valid... There is a lot of guidance improvement to do for this situation in SBN...

Hope it could help improve the tool üôÇ 

Cheers!

entry.title: Mass changes to purchasing info records - Excel formatting issue for price update
entry.content:
Hi Experts, 

We are facing an issue with the Mass changes to purchasing info records - Excel price update / upload function.

The app works well, also with offline upload/update but there an issue when values are copied from formulas in Excel:

  • When the amount in Excel is copied from another cel with a formula (but pasted as values) and has decimals (row 2 and below in the screenshot), the green triangle (error check) in Excel is not there (the value in row 1 is maintained manually and then it is there)
  • Cell is formatted as text

This error message occurs:

After double clicking in the cell or entering the same value manually, the green triangle appears in the cell. The cells are formatted exactly the same, but then no error occurs during the upload and it works perfectly fine:

Since the formatting is exactly the same, this does not make any sense. It seems to be something with Excel, but I have no idea what an my colleagues have the same issue. I cannot find anything related to this in the documentation / OSS notes or anywhere else.

Does anyone has an idea?

Thanks in advance,

 

Jasper

entry.title: Re: How to create the Picking WT via PPF based on the Pla...
entry.content:
Hi @Prabhakar_A1 

Thank you for your question.

In standard SAP EWM, warehouse task creation is typically based on delivery creation or the actual goods issue date. However, triggering tasks based on the Planned Delivery Date is not standard and would require a custom enhancement.

One option is to implement a custom BADI or background job that monitors deliveries with planned dates and triggers task creation accordingly. This ensures alignment between picking list generation and delivery planning.

I hope this provides more clarification. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Compatibility Scope: What Happens after 2025/2030
entry.content:
Dear Stefan,

Thank you for your clarifications, this helps a lot. Personally, I understand that due to the allowed/ carried over functions from ERP to earlier S/4HANA versions, the resolution for CP will mostly require the system conversion to latest S/4HANA version. Then depends on topics, the subsequent actions may require finding alternative solutions like LE-WM to Basic EWM or Advance EWM.  While the topic like CJ20N and other Project System functions may require Fiori applications. 

But based on OSS# 2269324 published last month, it mentioned that "For SAP S/4HANA systems under a RISE with SAP or SAP Cloud ERP Private agreement, the Compatibility Pack use right will expire Dec 31, 2030". So this case will be different than the system conversion to S/4HANA 2023 (or 2025 to be released) on-premise, private cloud?

Best regards,

Prinya

entry.title: SAP S/4HANA Cloud: Scheduling Background Jobs Using Application Job Templates
entry.content:
Introduction

In traditional ECC systems, developers typically used SUBMIT statements or function modules like JOB_OPEN, JOB_SUBMIT, and JOB_CLOSE to schedule background jobs. However, with the evolution of SAP to the S/4HANA Cloud and SAP BTP (ABAP Environment), the mechanism for job scheduling has changed significantly. The new paradigm revolves around Application Job Templates and the Application Job Framework (AJF).

Job Scheduling in ECC

In ECC, background jobs were generally handled through one of the following methods:

  • SUBMIT statements to run reports in background.
  • Function Modules such as:
  • JOB_OPEN
  • JOB_SUBMIT
  • JOB_CLOSE

    These methods gave developers control over job execution from within custom ABAP programs but were tightly coupled with the underlying system and lacked standardization in a cloud-native context.

The Cloud Paradigm: Application Job Framework (AJF)

In S/4HANA Cloud and ABAP Environment, SAP has introduced the Application Job Framework (AJF). This framework decouples job scheduling from the program logic and provides reusable, standardized, and secure job templates that can be scheduled through Fiori apps or ABAP APIs.

Key elements include:

  • Application Job Templates
  • Application Job Catalog
  • Fiori Apps for job management
  • APIs for scheduling via ABAP classes

Creating a Job Template

Job templates are defined using the 'Manage Application Job Templates' Fiori app. Each template is associated with an ABAP class that implements one or more of the following interfaces:

  • IF_APJ_DT_EXEC_OBJECT: For job design-time metadata
  • IF_APJ_RT_EXEC_OBJECT: For runtime execution

    These templates can then be reused across the system by both end-users and developers.

Scheduling Jobs Programmatically

To schedule jobs in ABAP code, SAP provides the utility class CL_APJ_RT_JOB_SCHEDULING_API. This class allows you to schedule jobs based on the template created in the catalog. Below is a basic example of how to use it:

*ABAP
DATA: LV_JOB_START  TYPE TIMESTAMPL,
               LT_PARAMETERS TYPE APJ_PARAMETERS_T,
               LS_JOB_RESULT TYPE APJ_JOB_RESULT,
               LT_MESSAGES   TYPE BAPIRET2_T.

LV_JOB_START = CL_ABAP_CONTEXT_INFO=>GET_SYSTEM_TIME( ) + 120.
APPEND VALUE #( NAME = 'S_ID' VALUE = 'RUN_ID_123' ) TO LT_PARAMETERS.

TRY.
    CALL METHOD CL_APJ_RT_JOB_SCHEDULING_API=>SCHEDULE_JOB
      EXPORTING
        IV_JOB_CATALOG_TYPE = 'ZMY_JOB_TEMPLATE'
        IV_START_TIME       = LV_JOB_START
        IT_PARAMETERS       = LT_PARAMETERS
      IMPORTING
        ES_JOB_RESULT       = LS_JOB_RESULT
        ET_MESSAGES         = LT_MESSAGES.
  CATCH CX_APJ_BASE INTO DATA(LX_APJ).
    " HANDLE ERRORS
ENDTRY.

Monitoring Jobs

Jobs scheduled using this API can be monitored via the Fiori app 'Monitor Application Jobs'. Here, you can check job status, review logs, and troubleshoot failed runs.

Benefits of Using Application Job Framework

  • Decouples job logic from scheduling logic
  • Reusable and standard job templates
  • Enhances cloud compliance and governance
  • Easy monitoring and error tracking via Fiori UI
  • Secure execution with authorization controls

Conclusion

With the shift to cloud-based ABAP development, it's important to adapt to modern, secure, and standardized approaches. Application Job Framework provides a robust solution for job scheduling needs in S/4HANA Cloud and ABAP Environment. Utilize job templates and `CL_APJ_RT_JOB_SCHEDULING_API` to build scalable and maintainable background processes.

entry.title: Re: PO header text & some other fields need to be display...
entry.content:
Hi,

The task card layout for Flexible Workflow in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition is based on standard UI annotations from the related OData service. Only certain header-level fields are exposed by default, and line item details, such as Material Number, are not shown.

https://influence.sap.com/sap/ino/#/idea/350271/?section=sectionDetails - The improvement request is confirmed to be within scope. Please monitor the request for updates.

Best regards,

SAP Support

entry.title: Re: Selecting participants and structuring the workshop effectively.
entry.content:
Thank you, Klaus, for your question.

You're absolutely right: getting the right mix of expertise in the room isn‚Äôt always easy, but it really does make a difference. Having both subject-matter experts and technical experts involved leads to more grounded and actionable ideas, and it might be better to plan the workshop with enough time in advance to find the right experts, rather than having only one perspective covered.

One way to maintain the balance between ideation and feasibility discussions is by creating space for different perspectives at different stages of the workshop. During the ideation exercise, participants work individually and silently, which encourages a wide range of creative input without immediate feasibility concerns. Later, in the prioritization phase, the group reflects together on which ideas are both valuable and viable ‚Äî and this is where technical experts can play a key role by identifying potential quick wins or flagging areas that might be more complex.

It‚Äôs also helpful to remember that this workshop happens early in the process. The goal isn‚Äôt to validate every technical detail, but rather to spot high-potential opportunities that are worth exploring further. Comprehensive feasibility checks will come later, during the design and implementation phases, when ideas are refined and solutions start to take shape. Often, what may initially seem difficult can be approached in creative or phased ways.

Thank You .

entry.title: partially committed webservice-transactions in SQL Anywhere
entry.content:
I am hosting webservice inside sql anywhere database, this works fine but I have from time to time problems with uncompleted transactions.
My code looks similar to this snippet.

create or replace table mytable (TS timestamp, msg varchar(100));
create or replace service myservice type 'xml' authorization off user dba as call myproc();
create or replace procedure myproc()
begin
insert into mytable values (now(), 'Start');
--long processing logic replaced with waitfor
waitfor delay '00:00:20';
insert into mytable values (now(), 'End');
select 'finished' from dummy;
end;

For some reason (when the processing too long time takes) I see partial transactions in MYTABLE ('Start' without 'End')

The Webservice is consumed from remote clients but with usual HTTP Calls. I cant exactly read what is the client getting in such uncompleted and partial requests, but probably timeout or 'statement interrupted by user'.

I dont have control on the client and can imagine that some timeout is set by it but how can the transactions of myproc be partially committed (I am sure that I dont have any explicit commit in myproc or somewhere else along the execution of myservice).

The same error could not be reproduced with curl (I call the webservice using curl and stop it after few seconds, then nothing is writting in mytable).

 

My Questions:

  1. Under what circumstances could a SQL Anywhere web service commit a partial transaction, even if there‚Äôs no explicit COMMIT?

  2. Could the SQL Anywhere engine implicitly commit parts of a transaction under some conditions (e.g., before an exception or client disconnection)?

  3. Is there a better way to structure or wrap the procedure to ensure atomicity, even in the case of client timeouts or interruptions?

  4. Is it possible to detect or handle client disconnections within the procedure?

Any insights or experiences with similar issues would be greatly appreciated.

entry.title: Re: Vendor Evaluation based on LIS - Conversion to S4 HANA
entry.content:
Although Simplification Note 2267414 permits retention of the classic vendor-evaluation solution during your S/4HANA conversion, the SAP S/4HANA Compatibility Scope Matrix (Note 2269324) grants only a limited usage right for all ‚Äúcompatibility-pack‚Äù solutions‚Äîand that right expires December 31, 2025. Your planned June 2026 go-live falls after this expiration, so the consequences of retaining the old vendor-evaluation logic are:

After 31 Dec 2025, you are no longer licensed to run the compatibility-pack component for vendor evaluation. Continuing to use it would violate your S/4HANA license agreement.

SAP will cease delivering bug-fixes, legal-change updates, or enhancements for the classic solution from January 2026 onward. Any regulatory changes to vendor evaluation (e.g., new scorecards, country-specific metrics) will not be back-ported.

Future S/4HANA releases (post-2025) may technically disable or remove compatibility-pack code entirely. Your conversion readiness checks and EarlyWatch Alert reports will flag the expired component as a high-priority finding‚Äîpotentially blocking further support package or version upgrades.

What you will see on your converted system is the existing IMG settings, reports, and SAP GUI transactions for classic vendor evaluation will remain visible immediately after go-live. However, any attempts to run batch evaluations or maintain settings will either:

  • Fail with compatibility-pack errors
  • Generate silent data inconsistencies that you cannot correct

Recommended approach is switch to Fiori-based Manage Supplier Evaluation and underlying CDS views. Migrate existing scorecards and custom KPIs using the delivered Data Migration Cockpit objects. Plan a cutover project to retire the classic logic by Q3 2025. Validate all interfaces and custom reports are re-pointed to the new framework. Monitor SAP Notes and Roadmap Explorer for deprecation schedules. Engage SAP Support via an OSS message to confirm any last-minute extension or workaround.

entry.title: Re: SAP Digital Manufacturing 25.05 Release enhancements and new capabilities
entry.content:
Hi,

As far as I remember, SAP Business Accelerator Hub only allows one Environment config for each Landscape. E.g. if you already have configured one for eu10, than it will not show up in the drop down list if you try to add a new environment. So you can just use the Environment you already created.

If that's not the case, you can raise a ticket for further investigation and support.

Hope it helps! Br, Manoel
